definition[0]: a small ball made of a strong-smelling chemical, used for keeping moths away from clothes
definition[1]: to stop using a factory, equipment etc or to not continue with a plan, temporarily but possibly for a long time
example[0]: The hospital manager said the project would be mothballed until funding became available.
definition[2]: if an organization mothballs a factory, building etc, it closes it or does not use it for a long time but may open it or use it again in the future
example[1]: The oil company plans to mothball one of its five refineries.
definition[3]: if an organization mothballs plans, it decides not to use them for the moment but may possibly use them later
example[2]: No decisions have been made to mothball the project.
definition[4]: if a building, factory etc or a plan is put in mothballs, it is no longer used but may be used later. If is taken out of mothballs, it is used again
example[3]: A number of its distillieries have been put in mothballs.
